* Let <math display="inline">W</math> be a set with a reflexive linear ordering <math display="inline">\le</math>, then <math display="inline">W</math> is said to be well-ordered by <math display="inline">\le</math> if and only if for every non-empty subset <math display="inline">A</math> of <math display="inline">W</math> there is a smallest <math display="inline">x \in A</math> such that for all <math display="inline">y \in A, x \le y</math>. 

== Remarks ==
* The corresponding strict linear ordering <math display="inline"><</math> will also be called a well-ordering
* Note that for any finite <math display="inline">X</math>, then any linear ordering of it is a well-ordering
* We know that <math>W</math> must have a minimum element as it is a non-empty subset of itself

== Examples ==

* <math display="inline">\left[ 0,1 \right]</math> is not well-ordered as <math display="inline">\left\{ x: 0 < x \le 1 \right\}</math> has no smallest element
* <math>( \mathbb{N}, \le )</math> is well-ordered
* <math>\mathbb{Z}</math> is not well ordered
